>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>

>I think sometimes it may be desirable to assign a different
>innovation number connecting two of the same nodes.  This goes back
>to the debate about how long to keep a record of innovation
>numbers.  In the FAQ I give some reasons I chose to only keep them
>around for 1 generation.  In your proposed model, this wouldn't be
>an option.  Also, it's nice to know the order that connections
>appeared.  If you ever look at a NEAT genome you can tell how often
>connections are successful and in what order they were put togther
>by looking at their innovation numbers.  Aside from these concerns,
>your idea is still doable but you'd lose these capabilities.

I think I can live with that.

So...I've actually started coding.  YEAH!!!  And I have some questions.

For the initial state of the experiment, it is a population of one, assigned 
to an initial species.  Because there is only one, crossover can't take 
place.  So, elitism causes one offspring that is identical to the first.  
The rest are created through mutation, right?

Then, you have to analyze the mutants to see if any new species arose.  If 
my understanding is correct, you have some 'compatability threshold' that is 
tuned in order to give you the desired results, correct?  In this case, you 
would measure the degree of difference between each individual and the elite 
individual.  If the difference exceeds the threshold, a new species is 
created, and a second pass determines which of those two species each 
specimen belongs in.  During that pass, if one is found that is over the 
threshold, another new species is created, and the process begins again, 
until all members are assigned to the closest species, and none is over the 
threshold away.  Or something like that...gotta keep the species count 
limited.  Is that about right?
